quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 10 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 10.8: Factors Affecting Reaction Rate: Surface Area and Catalysts
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Physical state and catalyst influence on rate

questions.question: How does increasing the surface area of a solid reactant affect the rate of a reaction?
options: It increases the rate by providing more sites for collisions to occur.
It decreases the rate by spreading the particles too thin.
It increases the rate by lowering the activation energy.
It has no effect on the reaction speed.
questions.explanation: More surface area (like a powder vs. a chunk) means more reactant atoms are exposed and available to collide with other reactants.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the primary function of a catalyst?
options: It provides an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy.
It increases the average kinetic energy of the reactant particles.
It is consumed during the reaction to produce more product.
It shifts the enthalpy change (Î”H) to be more exothermic.
questions.explanation: Catalysts speed up reactions by lowering the 'energy hill' (activation energy) required for the reaction to proceed.

questions.question: A substance that slows down or stops a chemical reaction is known as a(n):
options: Inhibitor
Promoter
Enzyme
Substrate
questions.explanation: Inhibitors work by interfering with the reaction pathway or blocking the action of a catalyst.

questions.question: Why does a pile of flour not burn easily, but a cloud of flour dust in the air can be explosive?
options: The dust cloud has a much larger surface area exposed to oxygen.
The dust cloud has a higher temperature than the pile.
Flour dust contains its own built-in catalysts.
The dust cloud has a higher activation energy.
questions.explanation: Splitting the flour into tiny particles maximizes the contact area between the flour and the oxygen in the air.

questions.question: Which statement is true about a catalyst at the end of a chemical reaction?
options: It is recovered unchanged in its original chemical form.
It is converted into a gas and lost to the atmosphere.
It is incorporated into the chemical structure of the products.
It is completely used up and cannot be used again.
questions.explanation: Catalysts participate in the reaction mechanism but are regenerated at the end, meaning they are not consumed.

questions.question: Biological catalysts that speed up reactions in living organisms are called:
options: Enzymes
Hormones
Lipids
Carbohydrates
questions.explanation: Enzymes are specialized proteins that allow complex biochemical reactions to occur rapidly at body temperature.

questions.question: A 'Heterogeneous Catalyst' is one that:
options: Exists in a different physical state than the reactants.
Exists in the same physical state as the reactants.
Is made of at least three different metals.
Only works in endothermic reactions.
questions.explanation: An example is a solid catalytic converter in a car reacting with gaseous exhaust fumes.

questions.question: How does a catalyst affect the Potential Energy Diagram of a reaction?
options: It lowers the peak of the curve (the transition state).
It lowers the energy level of the reactants.
It raises the energy level of the products.
It increases the distance between reactants and products.
questions.explanation: The catalyst lowers the activation energy ($E_{a}$), which is represented by the height of the peak on the diagram.

questions.question: If you want to speed up the dissolving of a sugar cube in water, why should you crush it?
options: Crushing it increases the surface area for water molecules to collide with.
Crushing it increases the temperature of the sugar.
Crushing it lowers the activation energy of dissolving.
Crushing it turns the sugar into a catalyst.
questions.explanation: More surface area allows more water-to-sugar interactions to happen simultaneously.

questions.question: Does a catalyst change the total amount of product (yield) that can be formed in a reaction?
options: No, it only changes how fast the equilibrium or end point is reached.
Yes, it increases the total amount of product produced.
Yes, it decreases the total amount of product produced.
Only if the reaction is performed in a vacuum.
questions.explanation: Catalysts affect the kinetics (speed) but not the thermodynamics (the final amount of product possible).
